channel.title: It's Pretty OK
channel.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
channel.description:
Why don’t more bars serve beer in pitchers? How do you pick a song for karaoke? What does the word “home” mean to you?
Those questions range from silly to serious, but if you’ve ever pondered the answers to all three in a single day, you’re not alone. Pour yourself a cup of coffee, crack a 40, or anything in between, and join the gang here at It’s Pretty OK as we attempt to answer these questions and many more. We promise it won’t be boring.
channel.itunes:summary:
Why don’t more bars serve beer in pitchers? How do you pick a song for karaoke? What does the word “home” mean to you?
Those questions range from silly to serious, but if you’ve ever pondered the answers to all three in a single day, you’re not alone. Pour yourself a cup of coffee, crack a 40, or anything in between, and join the gang here at It’s Pretty OK as we attempt to answer these questions and many more. We promise it won’t be boring.
channel.itunes:subtitle: Why don’t more bars serve beer in pitchers? How do you pick a song for karaoke? What does the word “home” mean to you? Those questions range from silly to serious, but if you’ve ever pondered the answers to all three in a single day, you’re not alone.

item.title: Ep. 349: A Cookie Cutter Christmas
item.description: We need more Clark Griswolds
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: We need more Clark Griswolds
item.itunes:summary:
This week, the gang gets together to talk about Christmas lights and whether most people are performing up to Pierce's standards when it comes to decorating for the holidays. (Hint: They aren't.)
MUSIC: "Once in a Lifetime" - Talking Heads

item.title: Ep. 348: Snobbery for Snobbery's Sake
item.description: What does it even mean to say “good coffee is bad now”?
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: What does it even mean to say “good coffee is bad now”?
item.itunes:summary:
This week (definitely not back in October), the gang got together to talk about a blog post about “good coffee” and the places that purport to sell it. Are we pro-snobbery? Anti-snobbery? Or are there maybe different gradations of snobbery, some of which are okay and some of which aren’t? You’ll have to listen to find out.
MUSIC: “Doobie Ashtray” – Devin the Dude
ADDITIONAL MATERIAL: Good Coffee Is Now Bad (Jason Diamond on Substack)

item.title: Ep. 347: Yearnin' for Some Learnin'
item.description: Is book learning a thing of the past?
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: Is book learning a thing of the past?
item.itunes:summary:
Happy Thanksgiving, y’all! The gang gets together this week to talk about the way that learning has changed now that not only are they not in school anymore, but videos seem to have overtaken books as the way to get yourself some new knowledge.
MUSIC: “Get Over It” – OK Go

item.title: Ep. 346: Remembrance of Culture Past
item.description: Who says you can’t go back?
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: Who says you can’t go back?
item.itunes:summary:
This week, the gang talks about revisiting the entertainment products that previously brought you joy, and why coming back to a book again doesn’t necessarily feel the same as rewatching a movie or a TV show.
MUSIC: "Record Collection (feat. Simon Le Bon and Wiley)” – Mark Ronson & the Business Intl

item.title: Ep. 345: Lackluster Video
item.description: Wait, did they say DVDs?
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: Wait, did they say DVDs?
item.itunes:summary:
This week, the gang is together to talk about collections of physical media — especially DVDs. Strap in!
MUSIC: “Training Montage” – The Mountain Goats

item.title: Ep. 344: DRAFT TALK
item.description: The annual moment when you think “maybe this year will be different!”
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: The annual moment when you think “maybe this year will be different!”
item.itunes:summary:
With Max off the board this week, the rest of the gang gets together to talk about why sports drafts — the NBA draft in particular — hold such a strong allure.
MUSIC: “Silk Chiffon (feat. Phoebe Bridgers)” – MUNA

item.title: Ep. 343: FOURTHPOD
item.description: Whatever it is, let’s taco bout it
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: Whatever it is, let’s taco bout it
item.itunes:summary: Whatever it is, let’s taco bout it

item.title: Ep. 342: Hot Tub Pod Machine
item.description: A conversation that’s been simmering for a while
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: A conversation that’s been simmering for a while
item.itunes:summary:
This week, the gang gets together to discuss hot tubs, which Sean derisively refers to at one point as “human broth” but which were a fairly significant part of Max’s search for a new place to live. I feel like that’s probably enough for you to know in order to decide whether or not this episode is for you — not unlike hot tubs themselves.
MUSIC: “Always Rhyme” – Homeboy Sandman

item.title: Ep. 341: Choosy Cooks Choose...
item.description: What we cook when we cook at home
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: What we cook when we cook at home
item.itunes:summary:
Sean is gone this week for a reason that may or may not have something to do with Hard Mountain Dew, but that’s not going to stop the rest of the gang from convening to talk about cooking routines. What are the things that you make a point of only eating out at restaurants (or things that you only eat at home)? And can trying cooking some of those things at home ruin the special-ness of the restaurant occasion?
MUSIC: “Easy On Your Own” – Alvvays

item.title: Ep. 340: Where Have All the Rivalries Gone?
item.description: What makes the bitterest feuds in sports so great?
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: What makes the bitterest feuds in sports so great?
item.itunes:summary:
This week, the gang gets together to discuss whether the sports rivalry is still alive and well, particularly in professional sports in the U.S. How much of the seeming fade of these bitter rivalries is due to changing attitudes among new generations, and how much is dumb stuff like fantasy football and the ubiquity of legal sports gambling? And why do the greatest sports rivalries often have so little to do with sports themselves?
MUSIC: “TV Will Always Make Me Cry” – Alien Boy

item.title: Ep. 339: BEDtv
item.description: To tube or not to tube, that is the question
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: To tube or not to tube, that is the question
item.itunes:summary:
This week, the gang talks about putting (or not putting) a TV in your bedroom. What goes into that momentous decision? Also, Sean gets irrationally angry about an audiobook he listened to, and as always, Pierce apologizes.
MUSIC: “Hurricanes and Hand Grenades” – Jason Isbell

item.title: Ep. 338: College GamePod
item.description: Talking about all the pregame talking
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: Talking about all the pregame talking
item.itunes:summary:
This week, the Sports Bois™ convene to talk about the phenomenon of pregame shows, particularly for football. Two important notes:1) This was recorded before College GameDay actually went to Boone, NC, which produced (among other things) this phenomenal intro video voiced by Wright Thompson.2) Thanks to frustrating Skype connection stuff, the crosstalk/awkward pause conundrum is worse than usual!
MUSIC: “Let Us Die“ – King Princess

item.title: Ep. 337: An Honest LIV-ing
item.description: Talking sportswashing and whatnot
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: Talking sportswashing and whatnot
item.itunes:summary:
This week, the gang gets together to talk about the ways that the sports industry is changing, especially the introduction of Saudi oil money in the form of the new LIV Golf tour. And we get the most harrowing edition of “Pierce Is Sorry” yet.
MUSIC: “9 to 5” – Dolly Parton

item.title: Ep. 336: Sight Unseen
item.description: Dealing with moving when you can’t see the place in person
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: Dealing with moving when you can’t see the place in person
item.itunes:summary:
This week, the gang gets together to talk about a phenomenon they’ve all experienced in the last two years: the remote house tour.
MUSIC: “Hangover Song” – MJ Lenderman

item.title: Ep. 335: Still Tippin'
item.description: Paying a little extra
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: Paying a little extra
item.itunes:summary:
Because everything is cyclical, this week, the gang is talking about tipping. The pandemic has changed our relationship with the practice, and it’s time to discuss it again — especially now that more places are starting to phase tipping out in favor of added service fees and the like.
MUSIC: “Exhibit C“ – Jay Electronica

item.title: Ep. 334: The One About Home Workspaces
item.description: Where we work when we don’t work from work
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: Where we work when we don’t work from work
item.itunes:summary:
This week, Max, Pierce and Sean talk about the act of cultivating a home workspace — something so many of us have had to do in the last two years — and some of the ways that that process can maybe go wrong. Does Sean figure out in real time that he ought to rearrange a couple things in his apartment? Maybe!
MUSIC: “Gimmie Shelter” – Merry Clayton

item.title: Ep. 333: Three White Guys in Their 30s Talking About F1
item.description: Something new and different
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: Something new and different
item.itunes:summary:
You’ve never heard that before, right? Apologies if the audio is glitchier than usual.
MUSIC: “Kawasaki Backflip” – Dogleg

item.title: Ep. 332: The Overcooked Pork Support Group
item.description: What food do YOU remember from your childhood (but maybe not in a good way)?
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: What food do YOU remember from your childhood (but maybe not in a good way)?
item.itunes:summary:
This week, the gang gets together to talk about the foods that they ate frequently in their youth that they’ve had to grapple with as they’ve gotten older and started cooking for themselves. Spaghetti comes up a few times, as do the low-fat craze of the late ’80s and early ’90s and the fear of trichinosis that led every parent for multiple generations to cook pork way too long.
MUSIC: “(I’m) Screwed” – Titus Andronicus

item.title: Ep. 331: Going, Going, Juan
item.description: It’s Juan-Soto-trade emergency podcast time, y’all
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: It’s Juan-Soto-trade emergency podcast time, y’all
item.itunes:summary:
This week, the It’s Pretty OK Sports Brain Trust™️ convenes to talk about the Juan Soto situation. He’s turned down a contract from the Nationals that looks huge on paper but is not nearly as good as it might appear, and now the team is expected to trade him. Where does that leave Pierce, who has been clinging to his Nats fandom even after leaving the D.C. area, specifically because of Soto?
MUSIC: “Worth It” – beabadoobee

item.title: Ep. 330: A Return to Rulemaking
item.description: Bringing back a classic It’s Pretty OK format
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: Bringing back a classic It’s Pretty OK format
item.itunes:summary:
This week, the gang is back together for the first time in several weeks. What better way to celebrate than by revisiting a classic pod concept and seeing if we can’t make a rule for society to live by? This time, it’s about what is acceptable attire for a craft brewery — specifically, is it okay to wear another brewery’s T-shirt?
MUSIC: “Gotta Let It Go” – Joyce Manor

item.title: Ep. 329: Los Angeles Is Part of the Midwest Now, Apparently
item.description: The B1G gets even B1G-ger
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: The B1G gets even B1G-ger
item.itunes:summary:
This week, Sean and Pierce talk conference realignment. Heads spin as they attempt to understand the concept of a college athletic conference that stretches from Piscataway, New Jersey to Los Angeles.
MUSIC: “Elvis Is in the Freezer” – Ratboys

item.title: Ep. 328: Borrowed Nostalgia
item.description: On Stranger Things and “remembering” things you weren’t even alive for
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: On Stranger Things and “remembering” things you weren’t even alive for
item.itunes:summary:
This week, it’s just Sean and Pierce, and they’re talking about Stranger Things and the phenomenon of borrowed nostalgia. What’s different about this show as opposed to other prestige-TV period pieces like Mad Men or The Americans? And why doesn’t Sean like the Kate Bush song as much as everyone else?NOTE: This episode was recorded before the release of the Stranger Things season 4 finale release, but after we had watched the previous S4 episodes. There’s not much in the way of spoiler-type stuff, but keep that in mind — if you’ve been saving Season 4 to watch until you could binge the whole thing, maybe wait until you’re done to listen?
MUSIC: “Once More for the Ocean” – Slothrust

item.title: Ep. 327: That's What Makes U Beautiful
item.description: A chat about pretty campuses
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: A chat about pretty campuses
item.itunes:summary:
This week, the gang gets together to discuss what makes a college campus beautiful. Is it more than just having a picturesque quad and a few buildings designed in an aesthetically pleasing style of classical architecture? (Yes.) Pierce finally says something nice about Virginia Tech; how long will it be before he goes back to reflexively insulting them? (It’ll be less than a minute.) And we have perhaps our most thrilling Rolling Stone rock trivia question yet.
MUSIC: “Mulholland Dr.” – Bartees Strange

item.title: Ep. 326: It's McPodcast Season Again
item.description: On challenge burgers and other over-the-top menu items
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: On challenge burgers and other over-the-top menu items
item.itunes:summary:
This week, the gang is talking about “stunt foods" — the parade of food challenges (like the Steak ‘n Shake 7x7) and ridiculous seasonal items (like Burger King’s black-bunned Halloween burger) that fast food customers find themselves bombarded with. Is this all the fault of Hardee’s and their risqué mid-2000s burger commercials? And will Sean take more stances that are probably more anticapitalist than he intended for them to be?
MUSIC: “The Amarillo Kid” – Craig Finn

item.title: Ep. 325: Summer Treats Make Me Feel Fine
item.description: When the weather is hot, the sweet treats come out!
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: When the weather is hot, the sweet treats come out!
item.itunes:summary:
This week, the gang gets together to talk about the frozen delicacies that have sustained them through many a hot summer. Will Sean get overly regionally proud about the snowball and then rebut an argument about snowcones that no one actually made? You better believe it. Do multiple people on this podcast endorse the consumption of custard on scorching summer days? Incredibly, yes! And will Max be shocked to discover that the thing he thought was a Northeastern specialty is all over the place, just without the region-specific name? You’ll have to listen to find out.
MUSIC: “She Bangs the Drums” – The Stone Roses

item.title: A Special Advance Screening of Ep. 324!
item.description: On being the first one in the theater
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: On being the first one in the theater
item.itunes:summary:
This week, the gang is talking about the fact that Max went to a midnight movie premiere (no matter what time zone he saw it in). They discuss the phenomenon of the special early release of movies/books/video games/etc. before the conversation unexpectedly turns into a referendum on Kevin’s approach to capitalism. You know, normal stuff.
MUSIC: “Heavy Heart” – Bartees Strange

item.title: Ep. 323: Let Them Email About Cake
item.description: On corporate birthday wishes and exploding inboxes
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: On corporate birthday wishes and exploding inboxes
item.itunes:summary:
This week, the gang gets together to talk about the fact that Pierce is still getting email updates from local businesses in a town he hasn’t lived in in nearly two full years. How has everyone’s inbox gone so crazy? Can Pierce convince us that he’s actually in the right somehow? And is Max ever going to check his damn email?
MUSIC: “Intervention” – A Giant Dog

item.title: Ep. 322: Trust the Pod-Cess
item.description: Death, taxes, and Daryl Morey’s project falling short yet again
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: Death, taxes, and Daryl Morey’s project falling short yet again
item.itunes:summary:
This week, the Sports Bois™️ are together to talk about yet another NBA conference finals that finds itself without Joel Embiid and the Philadelphia 76ers. And while Sean would probably like to spend the entire pod taking a victory lap about that, it fortunately turns into a broader discussion about the dangers of sports teams taking an entirely long-term (or short-term, for that matter) approach.
MUSIC: “I Don’t Live Here Anymore (feat. Lucius) – The War on Drugs

item.title: Ep. 321: I Pod, You Pod, We All Pod About iPods
item.description: A send-off to the device that changed music
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: A send-off to the device that changed music
item.itunes:summary:
This week, Sean talks to Pierce and Max about “the end of the iPod” and what it means. He also reveals that he is, in the year of our lord two thousand and twenty-two, the owner of a still-thriving (modified) iPod and tries to explain why he is the perfect target audience for the iPod modding craze.
MUSIC: “Chaise Longue” – Wet Leg
ADDITIONAL MATERIAL: An Ode to the iPod Classic (The Ringer) || iPod Modders Give Apple’s Abandoned Music Player New Life (WIRED)

item.title: Ep. 320: To Recommend or Not to Recommend
item.description: Is it really better to give than to receive?
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: Is it really better to give than to receive?
item.itunes:summary:
This week, the gang gets together to discuss recommendations. Is it better to get a good recommendation or to give one? Does the decision change if it’s not about a good recommendation, but just any recommendation? And why are we all so self-centered? Plus, a Pierce apology and a trivia question about unlikely high school classmates.
MUSIC: “Detective Lieutenant” – Drug Church

item.title: Ep. 319: The Great Revisitation
item.description: A look back at the movies we used to love
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: A look back at the movies we used to love
item.itunes:summary:
This week, Sean is back and the full gang is talking about revisiting movies that you used to watch when you were a kid. Just how goofy is the Ewok storyline from Return of the Jedi? Was his portrayal of the Scorpion King really what catapulted Dwayne “The Rock” Johnson towards becoming the biggest movie star in the world? And is the fact that Flubber is only about 90 minutes long enough to offset the fact that it’s, well, Flubber?
MUSIC: “Without Me” – Eminem
ADDITIONAL MATERIAL: Sean on the On the Record with Ambi podcast (Apple Podcasts) || Big Thief performs “Simulation Swarm” on The Late Show with Stephen Colbert (YouTube)

item.title: Ep. 318: Pod-triot's Day
item.description: Town gatherings galore
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: Town gatherings galore
item.itunes:summary:
This week, the gang gets together (minus Sean) to talk about local celebrations. Not so much the big things that gain a national reputation like Mardi Gras or the cherry blossom festival in DC — more like your small-town strawberry fests and whatnot. Plus, as always, Pierce apologizes, and we have a rock trivia question.
MUSIC: ”Now & Later Gators” – Freddie Gibbs, Curren$y and the Alchemist

item.title: Ep. 317: (Company) Swag Surfin'
item.description: Talking about those co-branded Patagonia vests
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: Talking about those co-branded Patagonia vests
item.itunes:summary:
This week, the gang convenes to talk about the various perks that are afforded to the modern knowledge worker by their employer — especially all the branded jackets and backpacks and such. How should we feel about being made walking billboards for our companies? And what happens when we don’t work there anymore?Somewhat predictably, Sean lashes out at corporate America, although it may just be because he’s not getting any swag at work. And there’s a Mad Men reference…but it’s not from Pierce for once.
MUSIC: “Country” – Good Morning
ADDITIONAL MATERIAL: What ‘Severance’ Gets Right About Infantilizing Office Perks (The New York Times)

item.title: Ep. 316: WePodded
item.description: Talking about the flood of “CE-shOws”
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: Talking about the flood of “CE-shOws”
item.itunes:summary:
This week, the gang talks about the flood of entertainment content based around problematic tech CEOs like Travis Kalanick (Uber), Elizabeth Holmes (Theranos), and Adam Neumann (WeWork). Why are there so many books, shows, podcasts, podcasts based on books, shows based on podcasts, etc. about these people?
MUSIC: “Halfway Out the Door” – Romero

item.title: Ep. 315: The One About Awards Shows
item.description: Who’s still watching them in 2022?
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: Who’s still watching them in 2022?
item.itunes:summary:
This week, it’s just Sean and Pierce, and they’re trying to talk about the Academy Awards — and awards shows in general — while desperately avoiding any discussion of the only part of the Oscars that anyone really seems to be talking about. Did it work? Hard to say.
MUSIC: “Change Your Mind” – BAD MOVES

item.title: Ep. 314: Live from the 919
item.description: Talkin’ bout tasty beverages, y’all
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: Talkin’ bout tasty beverages, y’all
item.itunes:summary:
Unfortunately, the initial version of Episode 314 was lost to a technical issue. But in exchange for waiting it out for a week, you get an extra special version of the pod recorded LIVE from the triumphant return of the It’s Pretty OK “Corporate Retreat”/NCAA Tournament Trip!After a night of drinking many — and we do mean many — tiki drinks in Raleigh, first-time/long-time Robert joins the gang to discuss cocktails and whether or not they should be a little bit disgusting.
MUSIC: “Phantoms (feat. Open Mike Eagle and Kendra Morris)” – Czarface & MF DOOM

item.title: Ep. 313: The Coach K Farewell Tour Special
item.description: On long goodbyes that maybe last a little too long?
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: On long goodbyes that maybe last a little too long?
item.itunes:summary:
This week, the gang is talking about what has certainly felt like the most hyped sporting event of our lifetimes: Duke basketball coach Mike Krzyzewski’s final regular-season game against North Carolina. Are they talking about the game itself? Of course not. They explore why it feels so weird to have farewell tours for coaches — or for any individuals in team sports, for that matter — and how this is probably all ESPN’s fault.
MUSIC: “Stuck” – Oceanator

item.title: Ep. 312: Poddle
item.description: Talking about the latest gaming craze
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: Talking about the latest gaming craze
item.itunes:summary:
This week, the gang is talking about Wordle and other games that don’t let you do infinite play. Does it turn into a minor squabble over Wordle “hard mode”? Sure does. Does it then segue into a grim look at the future of the ever-consolidating entertainment industry? You better believe it!
MUSIC: “The Hardest Cut” – Spoon

item.title: Ep. 311: Feeding the Content Beast
item.description: Talking about the Great Netflix Explosion™️
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: Talking about the Great Netflix Explosion™️
item.itunes:summary:
This week, the gang is talking about Netflix and the explosion of approximately 8 billion new shows of varying quality, seemingly tuned to every possible combination of micro-interests. What’s the deal with that? And why does Sean hate the word “content” so much?
MUSIC: “Amber” – 311

item.title: Ep. 310: Dem Franchise Boyz PART 2!
item.description: Evaluating a new generation of NBA superstars
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: Evaluating a new generation of NBA superstars
item.itunes:summary:
This week, Sean, Pierce and Kevin revisit a conversation they had way back in November 2016 about which NBA star you’d want to build a franchise around. They’re pretty sure they all got it wrong (some more hilariously than others), so they try to assess who were the actual right answers back in 2016 — and then run it back to draft from a new generation of superstars.
MUSIC: “Nuthin' But a 'G' Thang” – Dr. Dre and Snoop Dogg

item.title: Ep. 309: It's a Matter of Perspection
item.description: Talking about the way we watch sports, y’all
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: Talking about the way we watch sports, y’all
item.itunes:summary:
This week, the gang is all together to talk about the way that we watch sports. Specifically, is the way that live sports are filmed for TV broadcast wrong? And what the hell does any of that have to do with cows?
MUSIC: “Gallo Pinto” – Daniela Andrade

item.title: Ep. 308: Hi, I'm Johnny Knoxville, Welcome to the Podcast
item.description: Is there anything funnier than someone getting hit in the face?
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: Is there anything funnier than someone getting hit in the face?
item.itunes:summary:
This week, Sean is back after missing last pod due to COVID, and he can’t stop talking about the fact that there’s a new Jackass movie coming out — so the gang talks about nostalgia for a certain kind of comedy that doesn’t get made all that often anymore.
MUSIC: “Be That Man” – Madeline Kenney

item.title: Ep. 307: Members, Only?
item.description: Should you join the club? Maybe!
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: Should you join the club? Maybe!
item.itunes:summary:
This week, Sean is on the injured list with a condition that may or may not rhyme with SHMOVID-19, so the rest of the gang steps in to have a discussion about membership programs. No, not like Costco (although Costco is mentioned) — more like brewery/winery memberships or season passes at ski mountains. They talk about how these programs can help you connect with a new community and revisit how dumb it was for Pierce and Kevin to get Wizards season tickets way back when.
MUSIC: “Be a Part” – Dinosaur Jr.

item.title: Ep. 306: Calling an Audible
item.description: They’re like books, but for your earballs
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: They’re like books, but for your earballs
item.itunes:summary:
This week, Sean, Max and Pierce talk about audiobooks — a thing they’ve definitely never done before. Sean’s been revising his stance on them. He even made a ham-fisted attempt at defining some audiobook rules for himself…and then broke them almost immediately. But maybe it was a good thing that he did? Plus, another riveting installment of Rolling Stone Rock Trivia Calendar Trivia™️.
MUSIC: “Bunny Is A Rider” – Caroline Polachek

item.title: Ep. 305: SPORTS POD GO DAWGS
item.description: All hail Stetson Bennett, the future Chevy King of South Georgia
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: All hail Stetson Bennett, the future Chevy King of South Georgia
item.itunes:summary:
This week, the gang does an honest to god sports pod: they’re talking about the national championship game won by Georgia. Is Georgia defensive tackle Jordan Davis the largest man who has ever lived? (Maybe!) Remember when Brent Musburger was super horny on national television that time? (Hell yes, I do!) And will Sean stop trying to turn this into a rant about Chargers coach Brandon Staley calling that timeout? (Honestly, probably not!)
MUSIC: “Up from Below” – Remember Sports

item.title: Ep. 304: Peyton Manning, Shailene Woodley and Aaron Rodgers Walk Into a Bar
item.description: Who’s a celebrity, and who’s just famous?
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: Who’s a celebrity, and who’s just famous?
item.itunes:summary:
It’s 2022, and the gang is back to its routine of probing the depths of Pierce’s brain on a weekly basis. This time, they’re talking about the nature of celebrity — especially as it relates to athletes. If you stick around for a few minutes, you’ll get to hear Sean uncork what may be a pretty silly opinion about the relative fame of Aaron Rodgers and Shailene Woodley.
MUSIC: “Going Down the Road Feelin’ Bad” – Lucinda Williams & Friends

item.title: Ep. 303: A (Holiday) Tradition Very Much Like Many Others
item.description: Who’s carving the roast beast this year?
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: Who’s carving the roast beast this year?
item.itunes:summary:
Happy holidays, y’all! This week, the gang talks about what happens when it’s time to pass the responsibility for upholding existing traditions on to new faces/generations/etc., or to develop new traditions altogether. Christmas lasagna, anyone?
MUSIC: “Back Door Santa” – Clarence Carter
ADDITIONAL MATERIALMeet the Investigators podcast: Pandora Papers special edition (ICIJ) || The World of Five-Star (Apple Podcasts)

item.title: Ep. 302: You're Talking About Playoffs?
item.description: Is the postseason…basically just the season now?
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: Is the postseason…basically just the season now?
item.itunes:summary:
This week, the gang talks about the expanded seven-team playoff setup that the NFL is moving to this year. How does it compare to the NBA play-in tournament? Are they just asking for more players to get hurt or catch COVID-19? And most importantly, what basketball player is Nicolas Cage most like?
MUSIC: “Love and Communication” – Cat Power

item.title: Ep. 301: Ugly Christmas Sweater Podcast
item.description: Why are fast-food joints selling you holiday clothing?
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: Why are fast-food joints selling you holiday clothing?
item.itunes:summary:
This week, the gang is talking about “ugly Christmas sweaters.” Where did this phenomenon come from, and how the hell did it get hijacked by Popeye’s?
MUSIC: “Hurt A Fly” – Squirrel Flower

item.title: Ep. 300: Are You Mad, Max?
item.description: Another classic It’s Pretty OK watch-along
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: Another classic It’s Pretty OK watch-along
item.itunes:summary:
This week, it’s the 300th episode of It’s Pretty OK. We did an episode about 40s for Episode 40 and online dating specials for Episodes 100 and 201, so it’s only natural that the gang would do another special thing for this major milestone. This time, it’s a watch-along, and for #300, there’s only one movie that we could do a podcast on … right?
MUSIC: “Pretty Pictures” – Indigo De Souza
ADDITIONAL MATERIAL: Adam McKay Says Will Ferrell Won’t Speak to Him (Vulture)
